instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No Power - 20V 0.02A
threads.message:
Hi people !

I have a very clean board there, no liquid damage, that doesn't turn on. It seems it overheated around T2 Chip, on the back of it some resistors are kind of brownish (maybe it's just baked dust, IDK). I tried to restore T2 Chip but it is not enable to complete the process, always end with an error (tried with different host Mac, different OS, and official Apple cables).

I made some mesurements :
[LIST]
[*]PPBUS : 12.7V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> : 5.1V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> : 1.8V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> : 0V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> : 0V
[/LIST]
After that I guessed the RAM was not supplied, so I check around his buck controller <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>. It is well supplied by 5V, but nothing comes out because it's not telling to (0V on pin 16 and 17). As these signals comes from the PMIC, I think it is the culprit, but I am not used to work on these models at the moment, so not really sure.

I'd like to know if I missed something and if there is some steps to check before I remove the PMIC and try to replace it.

Thank you for your time, Bye

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No Power - 20V 0.02A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No Power - 20V 0.02A
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos,

Here are the SSD voltages that I have :
[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> : 2.5V --> It seems I have a short there, 60ohms seems not right for this rail, I don't have a board to compare but on a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board that is similar I have way more
[*]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> : 1.8V
[*]<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> : 0.9V
[/LIST]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No Power - 20V 0.02A
threads.message:
You cannot expect RAM voltage, if DFU can't be completed.
May have internal T2 problem, or SSD.

Sometime DFU can be completed after several days trying.
Apple did a "good job" with the f***g T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No Power - 20V 0.02A
threads.message:
Well understood. I don't know how the DFU could suddenly be completed if I don't change anything on the board, is it kind of mystic shit ?

Joke besides, I ordered SSD voltage regulator (<CHIP>U9000</CHIP>), worth the try, I'll keep you tuned on this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No Power - 20V 0.02A
threads.message:
You can use power on sequence from 01055, or 01598 boards; available on the forum.
<CHIP>U9000</CHIP> requires more than simple enable signal.
It is controlled by T2.
